answers.answerText: A. Disruption of the ellipsoid zone
answers.explanation:
The right eye OCT macula image demonstrates notable irregularities of the ellipsoid zone, which is the hyper-reflective line just anterior to the RPE (blue arrows). There is also hyper-reflectivity in the outer nuclear layer extending towards the RPE (red arrows), which can also be seen in the acute phase of this condition. The left eye OCT macula was unremarkable.

![](/content/media/uveitis_16_3.webp)

answers.answerText: C. Disorganization of the inner retinal layers

questions.title: Question 1
questions.text: What is the main finding in the right eye OCT macula image above?

questions.title: Question 2
questions.text:
Next, intravenous fluorescein angiography was conducted. The early and late phase IVFA of the right eye, and late phase of the left eye, are shown below:

![](/content/media/699564_71f3f5a6209440a49e32dcf945e575c5~mv2.webp)

![](/content/media/699564_781e0cc2e73d452992850a6424f2da75~mv2.webp)

What is the main finding of the IVFA images above?

answers.answerText: A. Early hyperfluorescence with late staining
B. Early hypofluorescence with late staining
answers.explanation:
The key finding of the IVFA images is hypofluorescence, from blockage of the signal by the placoid lesions (blue arrows), followed by hyperfluorescence via staining in late phases (red arrows). There are neither regions that demonstrate hyperfluorescence early, nor hyperfluorescence that increases in size and intensity in keeping with leakage; one can also correlate a lack of leakage to a paucity of intra- and subretinal fluid on OCT imaging.

![](/content/media/699564_ec6f177e46c7491a8f713d09940a1536~mv2.webp)

![](/content/media/699564_9df089e54eb745a692db7b08c5ce0ebe~mv2.webp)

answers.answerText: C. Early hypofluorescence with late blockage
D. Early hyperfluorescence with late hypofluorescence

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text: Based on the patient demographics, history, fundus photos, OCT images, and IVFA results above, what is the most likely diagnosis?

answers.answerText: C. Multiple evanescent white dot syndrome (MEWDS)
D. Acute posterior multifocal placoid pigment epitheliopathy (APMPPE)
answers.explanation: APMPPE is an inflammatory chorioretinopathy that is classified as a “white-dot syndrome.” APMPPE is typically bilateral and presents in patients in their 2nd - 4th generation of life. There is no sex predilection. Patients typically present with central or paracentral scotomas, as well as photopsias. There is occasionally a viral prodrome leading up to visual changes. Classic findings on fundus examination are large gray-white or creamy lesions at the level of the RPE. OCT imaging classically demonstrates loss of the ellipsoid zone with hyper-reflectivity in the outer retina and RPE mottling. The classic presentation on IVFA imaging is “early blockage with late staining,” as seen in our patient. Luckily, cases of APMPPE are typically self-resolving, with vision returning in 4-8 weeks. Steroids may hasten visual recovery, but there is no consensus on treatment. If there is poor visual rehabilitation or recurrence, an alternative diagnosis of relentless placoid chorioretinitis should be investigated.

questions.title: Question 4
questions.text: What alternative imaging modality should be ordered if a diagnosis of APMPPE is concluded?

answers.explanation: All patients with a new diagnosis of APMPPE should undergo a full neurological work-up for CNS vasculitis and associated conditions. Reports of optic neuritis, intracerebral hemorrhage, and encephalitis have been reported, but are less prevalent than CNS vasculitis. If relentless placoid chorioretinitis is believed to be the diagnosis, referral to Rheumatology for possible systemic immunosuppression should be initiated.

questions.title: Follow up
questions.text:
At the 6-month follow-up, the patient’s vision was 20/20 OD and 20/20 OS. Though more lesions were seen OU at the 1-month and 2-month the follow-ups, these demonstrated hypo-autofluoresence at this time and were not thought to be active. Her OCT imaging demonstrated marked improvement in ellipsoid zone integrity OD. Her MRI/MRA brain was normal.

title: Case 16
patientPresentation:
A 26-year-old woman of Hawaiian descent was referred to a tertiary uveitis clinic by her optometrist for a possible retinopathy in her right eye. The patient noted 1 week of seeing “gray patches” in her central vision OD. She denied pain, flashes, floaters of a visual field deficit. There was no viral prodrome. She denied past medical or ocular history. Review of systems was negative. Visual acuity was 20/70 OD and 20/20 OS. There was no RAPD. Anterior segment examination was unremarkable. Fundus photographs and OCT macula imaging was conducted and is shown below:
